{{Infobox Organization |name = Truth Initiative |image = Truth_Initiative_logo.svg |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |motto = Inspiring tobacco-free lives |formation = {{start date and age|1999}} |extinction = |type = Nonprofit organization |headquarters = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States|U.S.]] |location = United States |membership = |language = |key_people =[[Robin Koval]], CEO and president [[Mike Moore (U.S. politician)|Mike Moore]], chair, board of directors |num_staff =133 (2017) |budget = |website = [http://www.truthinitiative.org truthinitiative.org] |purpose=[[Tobacco control]], [[community outreach]], [[research]], [[smoking cessation]], [[public health]] |formerly=American Legacy Foundation (1999-2015)}}
'''Truth Initiative''' (formerly the '''American Legacy Foundation''' or '''Legacy''')<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=GsyDfvcFPEQC&q=%22American+Legacy+Foundation%22+ALF&dq=%22American+Legacy+Foundation%22+ALF&pgis=1 Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations]</ref><ref>[[PR Week]] (US) (March 5, 2007): p06. </ref> is a [[Nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] [[tobacco control]] organization "dedicated to achieving a culture where all youth and young adults reject tobacco."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truthinitiative.org/our-mission|title=Our Mission|work=Truth Initiative|access-date=2017-07-03|language=en}}</ref> It was established in March 1999 as a result of the [[Master Settlement Agreement]] between the attorneys general of 46 states, the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]] and five United States territories, and the [[tobacco industry]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/inside-the-hidden-world-of-thefts-scams-and-phantom-purchases-at-the-nations-nonprofits/2013/10/26/825a82ca-0c26-11e3-9941-6711ed662e71_story.html|title=Inside the hidden world of thefts, scams and phantom purchases at the nation’s nonprofits|website=Washington Post|access-date=2017-07-03}}</ref> Truth Initiative is best known for its youth smoking [[Truth (anti-tobacco campaign)|prevention campaign]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Farrelly|first=Matthew C.|last2=Nonnemaker|first2=James|last3=Davis|first3=Kevin C.|last4=Hussin|first4=Altijani|date=2009-05-01|title=The Influence of the National truth Campaign on Smoking Initiation|url=http://www.ajpmonline.org/article/S0749-3797(09)00074-9/fulltext|journal=American Journal of Preventive Medicine|language=English|volume=36|issue=5|pages=379–384|doi=10.1016/j.amepre.2009.01.019|issn=0749-3797}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Holtgrave|first=David R.|last2=Wunderink|first2=Katherine A.|last3=Vallone|first3=Donna M.|last4=Healton|first4=Cheryl G.|date=2009-05-01|title=Cost–Utility Analysis of the National truth® Campaign to Prevent Youth Smoking|url=http://www.ajpmonline.org/article/S0749-3797(09)00075-0/fulltext|journal=American Journal of Preventive Medicine|language=English|volume=36|issue=5|pages=385–388|doi=10.1016/j.amepre.2009.01.020|issn=0749-3797}}</ref><ref name="WaPo2013">Joe Stephens and Mary Pat Flaherty for the Washington Post. October 26, 2013 [https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/inside-the-hidden-world-of-thefts-scams-and-phantom-purchases-at-the-nations-nonprofits/2013/10/26/825a82ca-0c26-11e3-9941-6711ed662e71_story.html Inside the hidden world of thefts, scams and phantom purchases at the nation’s nonprofits]</ref> Its other primary aims include conducting tobacco control research and policy studies, organizing community and youth engagement programs and developing digital [[Smoking cessation|cessation]] and prevention products, including through revenue-generating models.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truthinitiative.org/our-mission|title=Our Mission|work=Truth Initiative|access-date=2017-07-04|language=en}}</ref> The organization changed its name from the American Legacy Foundation to Truth Initiative on September 8, 2015, to better align with its [[Truth (anti-tobacco campaign)|Truth]] campaign.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3049629/how-the-truth-campaign-plans-to-end-youth-smoking-once-and-for-all|title=How The Truth Campaign Plans To End Youth Smoking Once And For All|date=2015-08-13|work=Fast Company|access-date=2017-07-06|language=en-US}}</ref> As of 2016, the organization had more than $957 million in assets<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://truthinitiative.org/sites/default/files/annual_reports/AnnualReport-2016.pdf|title=2016 Annual Report: How Truth Initiative is working toward a tobacco-free future|last=|first=|date=|website=Truth Initiative|access-date=4 July 2017}}</ref> and a staff of 133 based primarily in its Washington, D.C. office.
== History == Truth Initiative was founded in 1999 as a result of the [[Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement|Master Settlement Agreement]] (MSA). The MSA was announced in 1998, resolving the lawsuits brought by 46 U.S. states, the District of Columbia and five territories against the major U.S. cigarette companies, to recover state [[Medicaid]] and other costs from caring for sick smokers. The four other states settled separately. The tobacco industry agreed to pay the states billions of dollars in perpetuity, making the MSA the then-largest civil litigation settlement in U.S. history. The states directed that a portion of the money they received from the settlement should be used to establish a national public health foundation dedicated to prevent youth smoking and helping smokers quit: the American Legacy Foundation, now Truth Initiative.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.naag.org/assets/redesign/files/msa-tobacco/MSA.pdf|title=Master Settlement Agreement|last=|first=|date=|website=National Association of Attorneys General|access-date=4 July 2017}}</ref>
In 2018, the Truth Initiative partnered with Office of National Drug Control Policy and the Ad Council to combat opioid addiction.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truthinitiative.org/news/expanding-our-mission-opioid-education-and-prevention-campaign|title=Expanding our mission with an opioid prevention campaign|date=2018-06-06|work=Truth Initiative|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/06/07/trump-administration-launches-opioid-education-campaign/676809002/|title=White House launches opioid education campaign that targets young people using shock value|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-09-10|language=en}}</ref>
== Activities ==
=== Truth Campaign === {{Main|Truth (anti-tobacco campaign)}}
Truth Initiative's signature program is its Truth campaign, a youth smoking prevention mass media public education program that has been widely credited with contributing to a significant drop in teen smoking.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.monitoringthefuture.org/pubs/monographs/mtf-overview2016.pdf|title=Monitoring the Future National Survey Results on Drug Use 1975-2016|last=|first=|date=|website=Monitoring the Future|access-date=4 July 2017}}</ref> In 2000, 23% of American 8th, 10th and 12th graders smoked. As of 2016, that figure was 6%.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.philanthropy.com/resources/audio/podcast-using-tobacco-money-t/6319/|title=Podcast: Using Tobacco Money to Stamp Out Youth Smoking|website=The Chronicle of Philanthropy|access-date=2017-07-04}}</ref> The campaign exposes tobacco industry practices as well as the health effects and social consequences of smoking.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.philanthropy.com/article/Advocacy-Group-Shows-How/234836|title=Advocacy Group Shows How Rebranding Can Rebuild Momentum|date=2016-01-07|work=The Chronicle of Philanthropy|access-date=2017-07-04}}</ref>
=== Truth Initiative Schroeder Institute === Researchers in the Truth Initiative Schroeder Institute publish dozens of peer-reviewed research articles each year with the goal of identifying methods to minimize the harms of tobacco use, measure the effectiveness of interventions and identify best practices for tobacco control.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truthinitiative.org/our-mission|title=Our Mission|work=Truth Initiative|access-date=2017-07-05|language=en}}</ref> Research is also done to assess the Truth campaign's efforts, both pre-and post-market, including the use of the longitudinal Truth Longitudinal Cohort (TLC) survey of more than 10,000 young people and a continuous tracking study to assess campaign awareness and message receptivity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3049629/how-the-truth-campaign-plans-to-end-youth-smoking-once-and-for-all|title=How The Truth Campaign Plans To End Youth Smoking Once And For All|date=2015-08-13|work=Fast Company|access-date=2017-07-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
In the early 2000s the American Legacy Foundation (as the Truth Initiative was then known) gave around $10 million of the settlement funds it managed to the [[University of California San Francisco]] (USCF) to help it formalize and expand the collection of internal tobacco industry documents that its library already hosted; the collection was then named the Legacy Tobacco Documents Library.<ref name=Hurt2009>{{cite journal|last1=Hurt|first1=RD|last2=Ebbert|first2=JO|last3=Muggli|first3=ME|last4=Lockhart|first4=NJ|last5=Robertson|first5=CR|title=Open doorway to truth: legacy of the Minnesota tobacco trial.|journal=Mayo Clinic Proceedings|date=May 2009|volume=84|issue=5|pages=446–56|doi=10.1016/S0025-6196(11)60563-6|pmid=19411441|pmc=2676127}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Press release: American legacy foundation's $15 million gift creates permanent home for tobacco industry documents at UCSF|url=http://www.scienceblog.com/community/older/2001/D/200114836.html|work=University of California - San Francisco|date=January 2001|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050409200744/http://www.scienceblog.com/community/older/2001/D/200114836.html|archivedate=April 9, 2005|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> As of May 2017, the library contained 14.7 million internal documents (nearly 89 million pages) created by major tobacco companies related to their advertising, manufacturing, marketing, sales and scientific research activities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu/tobacco/about/data/|title=Legacy Tobacco Documents Library|website=www.industrydocumentslibrary.ucsf.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref>
=== Community and Youth Engagement === Truth Initiative provides individuals, coalitions, and organizations information and methods to reduce tobacco use in their communities. The organization trains and educates young people interested in tobacco control and partners with community-serving organizations to reduce tobacco use. This includes a grant program for community colleges and [[historically black colleges and universities]] to create tobacco-free campuses.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truthinitiative.org/community-and-youth-engagement|title=community and youth engagement|date=2015-08-27|work=Truth Initiative|access-date=2017-07-07|language=en}}</ref>
Examples of youth activism programs include: * National Summit on Youth Activism: A training program for high school students that provides activism strategies, media training and approaches to community engagement * Youth Activism Fellowship: A year-long training program for young adults that prepares participants to carry out a tobacco control project in his or her community These community engagement programs are often an "on the ground" extension of the Truth campaign's work. Supporters of the campaign are called upon to support other anti-tobacco issues, such as a 2017 rally outside a Walgreens shareholders meeting in New York that was organized to pressure the pharmacy's board of directors to stop selling tobacco in its stores.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ny1.com/nyc/all-boroughs/news/2017/01/26/group-calls-on-walgreens-to-end-sales-of-tobacco-products-.html|title=Group Calls on Walgreens to End Sales of Tobacco Products|work=TWC News|access-date=2017-07-07|language=en}}</ref>
BecomeAnEx is a program that was created in 2008; it is a free, online community and set of resources for individuals who want to quit smoking.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.biomedcentral.com/on-health/2016/12/15/do-smoking-cessation-online-communities-actually-help-people-quit/|title=Do smoking cessation online communities actually help people quit? - On Health|date=2016-12-15|work=On Health|access-date=2017-07-07|language=en-GB}}</ref>
=== Innovations === The innovations center within Truth Initiative designs, builds and markets digital smoking cessation and prevention products that are centered around online social networks, text messaging and web and mobile applications. Any revenue generated by the innovations programs helps support other work at the organization.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truthinitiative.org/our-mission|title=Our Mission|work=Truth Initiative|access-date=2018-04-05|language=en}}</ref>
Examples of these programs include:
* BecomeAnEX: Created in 2008, BecomeAnEX is a free, online resource for individuals who want to quit smoking. Its website hosts a community forum and features blogs written by other smokers and ex-smokers that discuss quit strategies, challenges and successes. In addition to the online community, the site offers cessation tools, counseling, medication information and other cessation support services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.biomedcentral.com/on-health/2016/12/15/do-smoking-cessation-online-communities-actually-help-people-quit/|title=Do smoking cessation online communities actually help people quit? - On Health|last=Cutrona|first=Sarah|date=2016-12-15|work=BioMed Central|access-date=2017-06-10|language=en-GB}}</ref> * EX Program: Launched in 2017 in collaboration with [[Mayo Clinic]], the EX Program is a digital quit smoking program based on BecomeAnEx that health systems, health plans and employers can purchase and offer to their employees and members.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truthinitiative.org/news/how-employers-and-health-plans-can-save-money-and-help-people-quit-smoking|title=Digital quit-smoking program reduces the burden of smoking for employers|date=2017-05-10|work=Truth Initiative|access-date=2018-04-05|language=en}}</ref> * This Is Quitting: Designed for young adults, This Is Quitting is a [[mobile app]] that relays evidence-based text messages and other [[user-generated content]] to assist users in the process of quitting smoking.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truthinitiative.org/innovations|title=Innovations|last=|first=|date=2017-05-05|work=Truth Initiative|access-date=2017-06-23|language=en}}</ref>
== Leadership ==
=== Staff === Truth Initiative is led by a senior leadership team with representatives from each of its functional program areas. Headed by CEO and President [[Robin Koval]], this team includes:<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truthinitiative.org/about-us|title=About Us|work=Truth Initiative|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en}}</ref>
* Eric Asche, chief marketing officer * Derrick A. Butts, chief information officer * Dave Dobbins, chief operating officer * Amanda L. Graham, senior vice president, innovations * Tricia Kenney, chief communications officer * Anthony Thomas O'Toole, chief financial and investment officer * Anna M. Spriggs, senior vice president, human resources * Amy Taylor, senior vice president, community and youth engagement * Donna Vallone, chief research officer, Truth Initiative Schroeder Institute, * Ellen Vargyas, general counsel and corporate secretary *Robert Falk, general counsel<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://law.yale.edu/yls-today/news/robert-falk-90-named-general-counsel-truth-initiative|title=Robert Falk ’90 Named General Counsel of Truth Initiative|website=law.yale.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref>
=== Board of Directors<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://truthinitiative.org/board-of-directors|title=Board of Directors|last=|first=|date=2017-10-31|work=Truth Initiative|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en}}</ref> === {| class="wikitable" !Name !Position !Role !Location |- |[[Robin Koval]] |CEO and President |Director Ex Officio Truth Initiative |Washington, D.C. |- |[[Mike Moore (U.S. politician)|Mike Moore]] |Chair |Principal, Mike Moor Law Firm, LLC |Flowood, MS |- |[[Doug Peterson (politician)|Doug Peterson]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.naag.org/naag/committees/naag_standing_committees/representational-assignments1.php|title=NAAG {{!}} Representational Assignments|website=www.naag.org|access-date=2017-08-31}}</ref> |Treasurer |Nebraska Attorney General |Lincoln, NE |- |Georges C. Benjamin, MD |Director |Executive Director, [[American Public Health Association]] |Washington, D.C. |- |Nancy Brown<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bigdata.stanford.edu/2017-speakers/nancy-brown.html|title=Nancy Brown {{!}} Big Data in Biomedicine Conference {{!}} Stanford Medicine|website=bigdata.stanford.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.milkeninstitute.org/events/conferences/summit/milken-institute-public-health-summit-2016/speaker-detail/20727|title=Public Health Summit - Speaker: Nancy Brown|website=www.milkeninstitute.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-31}}</ref> |Vice Chair |CEO, [[American Heart Association]] |Dallas, TX |- |[[Herb Conaway]], MD |Director |Member, New Jersey General Assembly |Delran, NJ |- |[[Kemp Hannon]] |Director |Member, [[New York State Senate|New York Senate]] |Albany, NY |- |[[Gary Herbert|Gary R. == Awards and Recognition == In addition to [[Truth (anti-tobacco campaign)#Awards and praise|awards for its Truth campaign]], including being named among the top 10 ad campaigns of the 21st century,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://adage.com/lp/top15/#truth|title=Top 15 Ad Campaigns of the 21st Century - Advertising Age|last=Rodriguez|first=Ashley|date=12 January 2015|website=Advertising Age|access-date=23 June 2017}}</ref> Truth Initiative has also been recognized with the following:
* 2017 Alliance for Workplace Excellence Health & Wellness Seal of Approval<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.excellentworkplace.org/x-press/2017/General%25202017%2520Press%2520Release%2520-%2520All%2520Winners.pdf|title=Alliance for Workplace Excellence Announces Annual Award Winners|last=Alliance for Workplace Excellence press release|first=|date=26 April 2017|website=Excellent Workplace|access-date=10 June 2017}}{{dead link|date=August 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> * 2017 honoree, Center for Positive Organizations' Positive Business Project<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://positivebusinessproject.com/positive-business-practices/great-workplaces/the-truth-initiative/|title=The Truth Initiative|last=|first=|date=|website=Positive Business Project|language=en|access-date=2018-04-05}}</ref> * 2017 Inc. magazine top 10 Washington, D.C. companies with the coolest perks<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.inc.com/tom-popomaronis/these-companies-around-washington-dc-have-the-coolest-office-perks-spoiler-there.html|title=Feast Your Eyes on Some of the Coolest Office Perks That D.C. Has to Offer|last=Popomaronis|first=Tom|date=28 March 2017|work=Inc Magazine|access-date=3 April 2018|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20180516163245/https://www.inc.com/tom-popomaronis/these-companies-around-washington-dc-have-the-coolest-office-perks-spoiler-there.html|archive-date=2018-05-16|dead-url=yes|language=en}}</ref> * 2016 North American [[Effie Award|Effie]] Index top five most effective marketer<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://effie.org/press_room/177/detail|title=Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America & Grey Canada Win Grand Effie at the 2016 North American Effie Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=Effie Worldwide website|access-date=2018-04-05}}</ref> * 2013 Telly Awards Online Video Silver Telly and Bronze Telly<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tellyawards.com/winners/winners/list/?event=994&category=59&award=5&_p=17|title=34th Annual Telly Awards 2013 Online Video Bronze Winners|last=|first=|date=|website=Telly Awards|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-05}}</ref> * 2012 [[PRWeek]] Awards In-House PR Team of the Year honorable mention<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.prweek.com/article/1262516/prweek-awards-finalists-2012|title=PRWeek Awards Finalists 2012|last=|first=|date=|work=PRWeek|access-date=2018-04-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150521232951/http://www.prweek.com/article/1262516/prweek-awards-finalists-2012|archive-date=2015-05-21|dead-url=yes}}</ref> * 2012 Nonprofit PR Awards Annual Publication or Brochure honorable mention<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.prnewsonline.com/2012-nonprofit-prawards-annual-publicationbrochure/|title=2012 Nonprofit PR Awards: Annual Publication/Brochure - {{Infobox protein family | Symbol = lp_3663 | Name = Universal Stress Protein A | image = [[File:USP A domain.png|200px|UspA protein structure from ''Lactobacillus plantarum'']] | width = | caption = UspA protein structure from ''Lactobacillus plantarum'' <ref name="Tan K">{{Cite journal |vauthors=Tan K, etal | title=The crystal structure of an universal stress protein UspA family protein from Lactobacillus plantarum WCFS1 | journal=[[To be published]] | doi= 10.2210/pdb3fg9/pdb}}.</ref> | PDB = *3FG9 *1JMV *3S3T | Pfam = PF00582 | Pfam_clan = HUP | InterPro = IPR006016 | SMART = | PROSITE = | MEROPS = | SCOP = 1mjh | TCDB = | OPM family = | OPM protein = | CAZy = | CDD = }}
The '''universal stress protein''' ('''USP''') domain is a [[Protein superfamily|superfamily]] of [[conserved gene]]s which can be found in [[bacteria]], [[archaea]], [[fungi]], [[protozoa]] and [[plants]].<ref name="Siegele et al">{{Cite journal |vauthors=Siegele DA, etal | title=Universal Stress Proteins in Escherichia coli | journal=[[Journal of Bacteriology]] | volume=187 | year=2005 | pages=6253–6254 | doi=10.1128/jb.187.18.6253-6254.2005}}.</ref> Proteins containing the domain are induced by many environmental stressors such as nutrient starvation, drought, extreme temperatures, high salinity, and the presence of uncouplers, antibiotics and metals.<ref name="Siegele et al" />
In the presence of these stressors, ''Usp'' genes are upregulated resulting in large quantities of Usp [[proteins]] being produced by the [[Cell (biology)|cell]]. The over production of USP [[genes]] allows the [[organisms]] to better cope with stresses by largely unknown mechanisms. However, the USPs will alter the expression of a variety of genes that help to cope with stress.<ref name="Tkaczuk KL 2013">{{Cite journal |vauthors=Tkaczuk KL, etal | title=Structural and functional insight into the universal stress protein family | journal=[[Evolutionary Applications]] | volume=6 | year=2013 | pages=434–449 | doi= 10.1111/eva.12057}}.</ref>
==Function==
[[File:Haemophylus influenzae USP.png| 400px | thumb | The protein structure of a Universal Stress Protein found in ''Haemophylus influenzae'' <ref name="Sousa et al 2001">{{Cite journal | author= Sousa MC | title=Structure of Haemophylus influenzae Universal Stress Protein At 1.85A Resolution. | journal=[[Structure (journal)|Structure]] | volume=9 | year=2001 | pages=1135–1141 | doi=10.2210/pdb1jmv/pdb}}.</ref>]]
The primary function of this superfamily is to protect the organism from [[environmental stress]] such as exposure to [[UV light]], which may induce [[genes]] containing the USP domain in order to protect the [[DNA]] and more generally the cell from further damage.<ref name="Siegele et al" /> During '''bacterial''' '''starvation''' the USP genes upregulated will often arrest [[cell growth]] and promote its metabolism to adapt to sparse [[nutrients]].<ref name="Siegele et al" />
Recent research also suggests proteins containing this domain have functions beyond the realms of dealing with environmental stresses.<ref name="Nachin et al 2005">{{Cite journal |vauthors=Nachin L, etal | title=Differential Roles of the Universal Stress Proteins of Escherichia coli in Oxidative Stress Resistance, Adhesion, and Motility | journal=[[Journal of Bacteriology]] | volume=187 | year=2005 | pages=6265–6272 | doi=10.1128/JB.187.18.6265-6272.2005| pmc=1236625 }}.</ref> Nachin et al. demonstrated in ''[[Escherichia coli]]'' that USPs are involved in actions such as [[adhesion]] and [[motility]]. The researchers, through means of [[Gene knockout|"knocking out"]] USP genes known as ''UspE'' and ''UspC'', saw results suggesting an inability to swim and completely lack of motility, respectively. Conversely, mutants for genes ''UspF'' and ''UspG'' were shown to have enhanced swimming abilities. Therefore, mobility is affected both positively and negatively USPs within ''E. coli''. This demonstrates USPs influence throughout the cell could be widespread for a number of reasons.
Additionally, in ''Halmonas elongate'', there is a USP called TeaD has been described as a key regulator in the [[Membrane transport|transport]] of [[Ectoine]] across the cell membrane.<ref name="Schweikhard">{{Cite journal |vauthors=Schweikhard ES, etal | title= Structure and function of the universal stress protein TeaD and its role in regulating the ectoine transporter TeaABC of Halomonas elongata DSM 2581(T). | journal=[[Biochemistry (journal)|Biochemistry]] | volume=49 | year=2010 | pages= 2194–2204 | doi=10.1021/bi9017522}}.</ref> This demonstrates how versatile USPs can be. Their function, while primarily encompasses increasing survival during stressful conditions, is not always limited to this.
==Evolution== The ubiquitous nature of these proteins suggests the domain evolved in an ancestral species as well as highlighting the clear biological significance these proteins have in order to still be present the three domains of life. It has been suggested that the USP A domain was part of an ancient protein family. This is due to the similarity in structure between many distantly related organisms.<ref name="Aravind">{{Cite journal |vauthors=Aravind L, etal |title= Monophyly of class I aminoacyl tRNA synthetase, USPA, ETFP, photolyase, and PP-ATPase nucleotide-binding domains: implications for protein evolution in the RNA. | journal=[[Protein]] | volume=48 | year=2002| pages=1–14 | doi=10.1002/prot.10064}}.</ref> Aravind et al. confirmed these ideas with extensive evolutionary analysis. Aravind suggested that these proteins were part of a much larger protein structural family which was present and diversified in our last universal common ancestor for all extant life.<ref name= "Aravind" /> The original function has been suggested to be a nucleotide binding domain which was implicated in signal transduction <ref>{{Cite journal | author= Becker JD |title= The nodulin vfENOD18 is an ATP-binding protein in infected cells of Vicia faba L. nodules | journal=[[Plant Mol Biol]] | volume=47 | year=2001| pages=749–759}}.</ref>
==Structure== As the USP domain is widespread across many organisms, there is great diversity in the structures of these proteins. For ''Haemophilus influenzae'', its UspA resides in the cytoplasm. The protein forms an asymmetric [[Protein dimer|dimer]] with characteristic alpha and beta fold structures. There are differences among different bacteria in areas such as [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] [[binding sites]].<ref name="Siegele et al" /> In this case, UspA does not have ATP binding activity. Generally, USPs form dimers and have domains for [[nucleotide]] binding activity. However, as it is such a diverse group, often with little known about the exact structure, it’s not possible to comment on each USP. In addition to this, UspA may reside in different areas of the cell. For example, in this case it was in the [[cytoplasm]] but for others, it may be in the [[cell membrane]].<ref name="Sousa MC"> {{Cite journal | author=Sousa MC | title=Structure of the universal stress protein of Haemophilus influenzae.| journal=[[Bichemical Sciences]] | volume=9 | year=2001 | pages=1135–1141 | doi=10.1016/s0969-2126(01)00680-3}} </ref>
==Bacteria== Much of the research into USP is done on bacteria, specifically ''E. coli'' (Strain K-12). Consequently, much is known about the USP domains in bacteria. In ''E. coli'' there are six families of USP domains which are present in more than 1000 different proteins.<ref name="Bateman A 2004"> {{Cite journal | author=Bateman A | title=The Pfam protein families database| journal=[[Nucleic Acids Research]] | volume=32 | year=2004 | pages=138–141 | doi=10.1093/nar/gkh121 | pmid=14681378 | pmc=308855}} </ref> The six families are Usp A, -C, -D, -E, -F and –G which are triggered by differing environmental insults and often act via varying mechanisms.<ref name= "Bateman A 2004" />
UspA is the most commonly studied USP due to its widespread presence within bacterial genomes. UspA is especially implicated in the resistance of a huge number of stressors most notably tetracycline exposure and high temperatures, with the exception of not forming a response to cold shock. It is thought UspA is especially important to the recovery of ''E. coli'' following starvation of nutrients.<ref name="Siegele et al" /> UspA during normal growth conditions does not seem to influence gene expression. However, during stressful conditions such as carbon starvation, UspA has been shown to have a global influence on gene expression. A proposed mechanism for such a change in [[gene expression]] is that UspA has been suggested to bind to DNA. When UspA is mutated, ''E. coli'' becomes far more vulnerable UV induced DNA damage.<ref name="O'Toole R et al 2003"> {{Cite journal | author=O'Toole R | title=Universal stress proteins and Mycobacterium tuberculosis| journal=[[Research in Microbiology]] | volume=154 | year=2003 | pages=387–392 | doi=10.1016/S0923-2508(03)00081-0}} </ref> It’s important to note the USP responses are independent of many other stress responses seen in bacteria such as [[rpoS]].<ref name="Gustavsson et al 2002"> {{Cite journal | author=Gustavsson N | title=The universal stress protein paralogues of Escherichia coli are co-ordinately regulated and co-operate in the defence against DNA damage|journal=[[Molecular Microbiology (journal)|Molecular Microbiology]] | volume=43 | year=2002 | pages=107–117 | doi=10.1046/j.1365-2958.2002.02720.x}} </ref>
[[File:Bacteria USP response.png|400px|thumb | This schematic shows a generalised bacterial response to an environmental stress. In this case, it depicts increased levels of Nitric Oxide which stimulates ''Usp'' gene transcription. This results in an anti-stress response from the cell which may or may not include the responses listed within the diagram.<ref name="Zhang W et al 2013" />]]
The induction of USP proteins have also been implicated in transitions not only in metabolism or growth but in changes in the colonies' entire phenotype. Bacterial colonies can produce formations known as [[biofilms]]. Zhang and colleagues demonstrated that USPs may be involved in the promotion of intertidal biofilms.<ref name="Zhang W et al 2013"> {{Cite journal | author=Zhang W| title=Adaptation of intertidal biofilm communities is driven by metal ion and oxidative stresses| journal=[[Scientific Reports]] | volume=3 | year=2013 | pages=3180 | doi=10.1038/srep03180}} </ref> They observed that during stressful conditions involving metal ions and oxidative stresses that the biofilm phenotype would form. Upon analysis of these biofilms, it could be seen that there was a greatly upregulated level of UspA which Zhang suggests, may be involved with induction of biofilm formation. It is thought UspA may be involved in signalling processes which will upregulate genes involved with biofilm production.<ref name= "Gustavsson et al 2002" /> With findings such as these, it's beginning to be accepted that USPs are acting using an extremely wide range of mechanisms to ensure cell survival.
===Regulation=== In bacteria, the USP genes can be regulated by sigma factors within [[RNA polymerase]]s. This includes sigma factor σ70 which through binding to a single promoter region, upregulates the transcription of UspA in bacteria. The genes are regulated in a monocistronic fashion.<ref name="Kvint K et 2003"> {{Cite journal | author=Kvint K | title=The bacterial universal stress protein: function and regulation.| journal=[[Curr Opin Microbiol]] | volume=6 | year=2013 | pages=140–145}} </ref> Additionally, UspA, UspC, UspD and UspE are over induced during stationary phase through regulation of RecA. RecA is known for its involvement in the repair of DNA via [[homologous recombination]] following [[DNA damage|damage]]. Consequently, the four Usp domain genes are thought to be mediating the management or protection of DNA.<ref name="Diez A 2002"> {{Cite journal | author=Diez A | title=The universal stress protein A of Escherichia coli is required for resistance to DNA damaging agents and is regulated by a RecA/FtsK-dependent regulatory pathway.|journal=[[Molecular Microbiology (journal)|Molecular Microbiology]] | volume=36 | year=2002 | pages=1494–1503}} </ref> Whatever the mechanism exhibited by the proteins, one thing which can be concluded is that USP domains are crucial for survival of many bacterial species. Gomes et al. found that UspA deletions in ''Listeria'' severely impaired survival as well as listeria’s stress response by [[in vitro]] and [[in vivo]].<ref name="Gomes CS 2011"> {{Cite journal | author=Gomes CS| title=Universal Stress Proteins Are Important for Oxidative and Acid Stress Resistance and Growth of Listeria monocytogenes EGD-e In Vitro and In Vivo.| journal=[[PLOS]] | volume=6 | year=2011 | pages=e24965 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0024965}} </ref>
USP domain genes are regulated by a number of proteins involved with [[Cell growth|growth]], [[DNA repair]] and [[cell division]]. Notable positive regulation occurs via the action of [[ppGpp]], [[RecA]] and [[FtsZ]] dependent regulatory pathways. USP domain genes are also under the negative control of FadR. <ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/P0AED0 |title= The Universal Stress Protein A |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 2015-03-25|website= www.uniprot.org|publisher= Uniprot|access-date= 2015-03-25}}</ref>
==Plants== [[Plants]] contain many hundreds of USP domains and genes. These genes are notably induced by environmental stresses such as [[drought]]. When a lack of [[Tissue hydration|hydration]] occurs, biochemical changes induced by the actions of USPs ensue. In response to drought, there is a reduction in [[photosynthetic]] [[carbon]] production as well as a reduction in [[energy metabolism]].<ref name="Isokpehi RD"> {{Cite journal | author=Isokpehi RD | title=Identification of drought-responsive universal stress proteins in viridiplantae.| journal=[[bioinform Biol Insights]] | volume=5 | year=2011 | pages= 41–58 | doi=10.4137/BBI.S6061}} </ref> These actions are suggested to occur due to their implications in increasing energy conservation. Water limiting conditions are a common environmental pressure which plants will need to cope with on a regular basis, depending on their habitat. These resistant [[phenotypes]] will have an increased survival as they allow the plant to conserve energy in times of restricted water which is key to [[glucose]] production through [[photosynthesis]].<ref name= "Isokpehi RD" />
==Clinical significance==
===Tuberculosis=== [[Mycobacterium tuberculosis]], the infectious agent responsible for [[Tuberculosis]] (TB), persists within an estimated two billion people. TB is known for its ability to transition into a latent state whereby there is slow growth but high persistence within the mammalian host in structures known as [[granulomas]].<ref name="Ramakrishnan L"> {{Cite journal | author=Ramakrishnan L | title=Revisiting the role of the granuloma in tuberculosis| journal=[[Nature Reviews]] | volume=12 | year=2012 | pages=352–366 | doi= 10.1038/nri3211}} </ref> These granuloma structures are made up of various cellular materials and immune cells. These include macrophages, neutrophils, cellulose and fats. It has long been proposed that USPs play a significant role in the persistence of TB within the human host. This is due to observations of elevated ''Usp'' genes within ''M. tuberculosis'' in the latent granuloma stage of the infection.<ref name="O'Toole R" />
There are eight types of USPs within ''M. tuberculosis'', all of which have an ATP binding domain. It has been found that within ''M. tuberculosis'', these USPs are regulated by FtsK and FadR.<ref name="Drumm JE" /> One recent finding shows that the induction of USPs within ''M. tuberculosis'' results in USP binding activity with intracellular cAMP which has indirect implications on transcription within the bacteria.<ref name="Banerjee et al"> {{Cite journal | author=Banerjee A | title=A Universal Stress Protein (USP) in Mycobacteria binds cAMP| journal=[[The Journal of Biological Chemistry]] | volume=12 | year=2015 | pages= 1–28 | doi= 10.1074/jbc.M115.644856| pmc=4432290}} </ref>
Some of ''M. tuberculosis''' USPs are suggested to be induced by the [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxic]] conditions found within the granuloma. Specifically, Rv2623, a type of USP in ''M. tuberculosis'', is induced by the presence of [[nitric oxide]], [[reactive oxygen species]] and a downshift in [[pH]]. All of these conditions are suggested to be produced by the actions of [[macrophages]] which are particularly prevalent within the granuloma structures that are characteristic of TB latent infections.<ref name="O'Toole R"> {{Cite journal | author=O'Toole R | title=Universal stress proteins and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.| journal=[[Research in Microbiology]] | volume=6 | year=2003 | pages= 387–392}} </ref> These conditions have been found to upregulate a particular USP gene called ''rv2623'', as well as an additional 50 genes involved in long term persistence in the mammalian host. It was suggested this USP gene was involved in inducing the latent response within the mammalian host. This stage of the infection is currently chronic with no effective treatments. This makes these kinds of findings extremely valuable.
Rv2623 has an ATP binding domain which if knocked out results in a hyper-virulent form of the bacteria.<ref name="Drumm JE"> {{Cite journal | author=Drumm JE | title=Mycobacterium tuberculosis universal stress protein Rv2623 regulates bacillary growth by ATP-Binding: requirement for establishing chronic persistent infection.| journal=[[PLoS Pathog.]] | volume=5 | year=2009 | pages= e1000460 | doi=10.1371/journal.ppat.1000460}} </ref> Understanding these processes aids researchers in their quest to provide effective treatment for those suffering from TB. Rv2623 is also a key [[biomarker]] aiding the diagnostic process for TB. Therefore, these USP genes could be crucial for the long term survival of the bacteria meaning that there may be potential therapeutic avenues of research to explore in treating latent TB.<ref name="Hingley-Wilson"> {{Cite journal | author=Hingley-Wilson SM | title=Individual Mycobacterium tuberculosis universal stress protein homologues are dispensable in vitro| journal=[[Tuberculosis]] | volume=90 | year=2010 | pages= 236–244 | doi=10.1016/j.tube.2010.03.013}} </ref> This comes at a time whereby TB kills many thousands of people a day and is becoming increasing problematic to treat with the rise of [[Multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis|multi-drug-resistant TB]].
===Salmonella=== Similarly, USPs are crucial for the survival of [[Salmonella]], the causative agent in Salmonellosis. In [[developing countries]], food poisoning of this kind is a potentially life-threatening condition. The USPs have influence in growth arrest, stress responses and virulence.<ref name="Liu WT"> {{Cite journal | author=Liu WT | title=Role of the universal stress protein UspA of Salmonella in growth arrest, stress and virulence| journal=[[Microbial Pathogenesis]] | volume=42 | year=2007 | pages= 2–10 | doi=10.1016/j.micpath.2006.09.002}} </ref> UspA is induced by [[metabolic]], [[oxidative]] and [[temperature]] related stress. In these conditions UspA is over produced through the [[transcriptional regulation]] by ppGpp and RecA. These responses have been suggested to be involved in the protection of DNA. As a result, UspA aids Salmonella to resist stressors produced by the mammalian [[immune system]] assisting in survival and hence, pathogenicity.<ref name="Liu WT" /> When UspA is inactivated in Salmonella, the mutants die prematurely, demonstrating how crucial these proteins are to survival and persistence. Again, understanding these processes may aid researchers in developing effective drugs to treat these infections.<ref name="Liu WT" />
